item.title: RUDIMENTA LINGVAE LATINAE
item.author: Eugenio Pace
item.description: Latin is often called a "dead language." In the sense that people don’t normally use it for everyday conversations—except maybe in the Vatican.

item.title: LECTIO PRIMA (First Declension Nouns)
item.author: Eugenio Pace
item.description: Nouns (et. Nomen: name) is the name we give to things, people, and places; either generally (the city, the man), or specifically (Seattle, Marcus).

item.title: LECTIO SECUNDA (Second Declension - Masculine)
item.author: Eugenio Pace
item.description: Second declensions nouns are mostly masculine and neuter. Like first declension nouns, there's a base and endings for each case. Most ,masculine 2nd declensions nouns end in the (familiar) us. Many (masculine) names end in us too: Marcus, Aurelius, Lucius. Names, like any noun also decline, which I find neat.

item.title: LECTIO TERTIA (Second Declension - Neuter)
item.author: Eugenio Pace
item.description: Neuter nouns are plenty in the 2nd declension. Their Nominative end in -um. Nominative plural for the neuter is -a which can be easily confused with the (femenine) First Declension. Watch out!

item.title: LECTIO QVARTA (Adverbs)
item.author: Eugenio Pace
item.description: If Adjectives modify nouns, guess what adverbs modify? If you thought verbs, you are right!

item.title: LECTIO QVINTA (Prepositions)
item.author: Eugenio Pace
item.description: Latin relies much less than other languages on prepositions, given that the declensions and cases often convey the same meaning.
